text: every spring the skies of southern
Colorado's San Luis Valley filled with
the sight and sound of thousands of
migrating sandhill cranes there's
something about sandhill cranes the call
is really a primitive really resonates
deeply with in people and of course
these birds have been flying across
North America for millions of years
recently that primitive call has been
joined by the very modern buzz of this
machine this is a military-grade drone
called The Raven basically eight major
pieces the wings a fuselage that snaps
together hail the drone was donated by
the army to the United States Geological
Survey to be used for scientific
research here at the Monte Vista
National Wildlife Refuge the mission has
been counting and monitoring the health
of the cranes for the Fish and Wildlife
Service we need to do a good job of
assessing how many birds there are out
there so that we can ensure that there
are plenty of birds not only for the
viewing public but there are birds to
hunt and to make sure that that we
establish harvest levels that are
appropriate so that we can continue to
enjoy these birds for many many years
usually bird counts are done by a
biologist flying in a small aircraft
which can be dangerous seems like every
few years we hear of a colleague that's
either been injured or worse in in a
plane incident drones like the Raven can
be safer than manned flights may yield
more accurate data and be less expensive
to operate this is really cutting edge
for us
launched by hand then controlled by
pilots on the ground The Raven can be
equipped with cameras that can capture
images with resolution down to the
square centimeter but drones can still
be perceived as a threat by birds at
first during the day it did scare them
so we thought oh this isn't going to
work but each evening the cranes gather
together in the wetlands they're pretty
sedentary for the evening and we found
out that when we flew in the middle of
the night with thermal imagery the birds
really didn't move at all and what we
actually get from the videography the
thermal imagery looks like a lot of rice
grains on a dark piece of paper and so
what we can do then is use software to
identify the the pixels that make up a
bird and then we can have a machine
actually go through and count all the
birds for us the success of the cream
study has piqued interest in drone
missions other scientists are using
drones to search for marine mammals in
the Arctic and fly treacherous runs over
Idaho rivers to count threatened salmon
and where it really helps is when we're
in a tight canyon or in a real enclosed
area where it's dangerous for the pilots
to be flying in there to begin with
currently the Federal Aviation
Administration limits scientific drone
flights to governmental agencies and
public universities on an experimental
basis I think that the Federal Aviation
Administration and others are using a
go-slow approach on a lot of this
because of the potential for problems as
you get more and more of these vehicles
in the year with mounting interest in
the tools Congress has directed the FAA
to integrate drones into the national
airspace by 2015 if this technology
enables us to do things more safely as
well as more efficiently or fools not to
take advantage from the Monte Vista
National Wildlife Refuge in southern
Colorado this is sean patrick farrell
for the new york times
